awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Early research experience for undergraduates in coastal biology on Florida's first coast
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of North Florida (UNF), located in Jacksonville, FL, will host a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site that will provide ten students with a 10-week active learning experience each summer for three years.  The overall goal of the program is to enhance the training and career development of early stage (rising Sophomores and Juniors) undergraduate students who have not had prior research experience by engaging them in research on coastal biology. The program includes a one-week orientation and one-on-one mentoring for research projects. Students will also participate in professional development activities, complete a formal writing assignment and give both an oral and a poster presentation. Students will be encouraged to present their research findings at professional conferences and/or in manuscripts submitted to professional journals. 

The UNF REU Site will provide a total of thirty undergraduates with research internships over the three-year period. The program conducts a national search for applicants and seeks to engage students who are from schools with limited research opportunities. Most of the funding provided supports student stipends, housing and travel to attend the program. The focus of potential research projects for REU students at UNF includes growing threats to coastal ecosystems in Florida, such as anthropogenic pollution, invasive species, harmful algal blooms, impacts to fisheries, and habitat alteration. Students may also study basic physiology (e.g., ion exchange mechanisms, patterns of gene expression) and/or ecology (e.g., food web interactions, range shifts, hybridization) of coastal organisms in an effort to understand, among other things, how anthropogenic changes to coastal habitats alter these factors and influence coastal wildlife populations. Through their mentored research experiences paired with specific skills training sessions, students will gain an understanding of important issues in coastal biology and coastal environmental system. This project supports national goals of developing the next generation of scientists and the scientific workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our REU program hosted 10 undergraduates in each of the summers of 2019, 2021 and 2022 during which they participated in mentored research projects in a variety of subjects in coastal and marine biology. Our program focuses on providing research experiences to students that have only completed one or two years of college, or to older students that have not had opportunities to gain research experience at their home institution. We also aim to have a diverse pool of participants in an effort to help promote participation from groups of people that are currently and historically underrepresented in scientific fields. In addition to getting experience in conducting scientific research, participants in the program also take part in a variety of career development workshops to help prepare them for graduate school and careers in scientific fields.

Over the course of our program, 80% of the students involved had completed two years of college or less and 56.7% were from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences. Eleven of these participants presented the results of their research at regional, national or international conferences and one has been a co-author on a peer-reviewed publication to date. These activities enhance their ability to get into graduate schools and ultimately get jobs. 

Evaluations of the program from participants were generally positive, with most noting that they had gained confidence in their abilities to do science, their interest in going to graduate school had increased, and they had garnered skills in both conducting experiments and in communicating their results. The marjority of participants stated that they were planning on going to graduate school upon completion of their bachelors degree and suggested the program had prepared them for this through the research experiences and the career development workshops.

Overall, we would deem our program to have been a success. We met our stated goals for participation and the students involved in the program feel they are better prepared for a scientific career.
